intro: Brassica bunias, commonly known as field mustard, is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its cruciform flowers and segmented fruits. It is an annual or biennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with serrated leaves and yellow or white flowers. The plant produces small, three-lobed pods that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. It thrives in a variety of soil types and is often found in disturbed areas, roadsides, and agricultural fields. Brassica bunias is also known for its potential as a forage crop and its use in traditional medicine.
